prompt: Why is the most important number to guess in a “low bid” bidding situation (like most government contracts) the second lowest bid (the lowest losing bid)? How is that the most helpful number to guess for maximizing profitability?
title: Think the lowest bid always wins?
originalTitle: Why Estimating the Second-Lowest Bid is Key in Low-Bid Auctions
socialQuestion: Think the lowest bid always wins?
sceneDescription: A row of solemn businesspeople in dark suits stands before a government official seated at a long desk. Each person clutches a sealed envelope. One figure at the front, wearing a restrained grin, receives a handshake and a contract from the official. Another figure, envelope in hand, stands just behind, body language revealing a deflated realization. The official uses a tiny ruler to compare the edges of the two envelopes. The scene highlights the razor-thin margin between winning and losing in the bidding process.
